item.title: Inspiration & Resources
item.description:
Inspiration & Resources#

Projects, ideas and resources that influenced the creation of this project and that may come in handy.

  • forvo.com download audio in multiple languages
  • Ultimate Geography, a fantastic Anki deck that successfully demonstrates how to collaborate on multiple Anki decks
  • 625 words from Gabriel Wyner’s Fluent Forever
  • The “Fluent Forever” book by Gabriel Wyner
  • Xefjord’s language decks
  • Antimoon, with many valuable resources, for example why it’s important to prioritize pronunciation

item.title: Roadmap
item.description:
Roadmap#

A rough sketch where this could be going.

  • Allow learning from many language to many other languages (e.g. enable a native French speaker to learn Swahili)
  • Create minimal pair decks to learn pronunciation
  • Create language specific IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet) decks for learning what the IPA symbols mean and what sounds they encode to enable learners to efficiently use a dictionary
  • Create decks for learning the 625 basic words in any language
  • Create cards for learning vocabulary and grammatical structures according to levels (e.g. A1, A2, B1, …)
  • Create advanced monolingual decks e.g. for learning what pecuniary or peevish mean in English

item.title: Learning Tips
item.description:
Learning Tips#

Study Tips#

  • Study consistently: Daily practice is more effective than long, infrequent sessions
  • Speak out loud: For pronunciation cards, always speak the answer aloud
  • Use the audio: Listen carefully to native pronunciation on all audio-enabled cards
  • Don’t rush: Take time to recall the answer before revealing it
  • Be honest: Mark cards as “Again” if you couldn’t recall the answer quickly

Adjusting Deck Options#

Avoid learning too many new cards per day because it might quickly become overwhelming. The default value of New cards/day of 20 is a good start.
